description: John Spence is recognized as one of the Top 100 Business Thought Leaders in America, one of the Top 100 Small Business Influencers in America, and one of the Top 500 Leadership Development Experts in the World. John created this series of seven courses covering essential teambuilding skills created specifically for technology teams.
name: Leading Technology Teams
subtitle: Leading Technology Teams

episodes.description: This session covers the stages of team development, what type of team to create, the ideal team member model, and picking the right people for your team.
episodes.title: Launching a Successful Team
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.051
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.051 --> 00:00:05.931
[SOUND] Hello, and welcome to BizProTV.

3
00:00:05.931 --> 00:00:07.881
I'm your host, Peter VanRysdam,

4
00:00:07.881 --> 00:00:11.201
and today we're talking about
building successful teams.

5
00:00:11.201 --> 00:00:12.381
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:12.381 --> 00:00:15.980
we're talking about starting from
the beginning and launching that team.

7
00:00:15.980 --> 00:00:19.860
And here to help us, we have an expert
on all things business related, Mr.

8
00:00:19.860 --> 00:00:21.150
John Spence, John, how you doing?

9
00:00:21.150 --> 00:00:22.650
>> Doing fantastic, Peter, and you?

10
00:00:22.650 --> 00:00:23.420
>> I'm great, thank you.

11
00:00:23.420 --> 00:00:24.040
>> Excellent.

12
00:00:24.040 --> 00:00:27.410
>> John tell us a little bit
about yourself to get us started.

13
00:00:27.410 --> 00:00:32.290
>> More than 20 years as a leadership and
strategy, and business trainer,

14
00:00:32.290 --> 00:00:33.460
and consultant.

15
00:00:33.460 --> 00:00:36.940
I've written five books, and
this is what I've built my career around,

16
00:00:36.940 --> 00:00:38.960
is trying to help people
improve in business.

17
00:00:38.960 --> 00:00:42.600
Fantastic, all right, so we're talking
about launching successful teams.

18
00:00:42.600 --> 00:00:45.740
There are so many places to start,
where do we start on this?

19
00:00:45.740 --> 00:00:50.060
>> Well, I like to start with what's a
pretty famous model done by Bruce Tuckman

20
00:00:50.060 --> 00:00:51.945
about the five stages of teams.

21
00:00:51.945 --> 00:00:56.555
And that's forming, storming,
norming, performing, and

22
00:00:56.555 --> 00:00:58.910
then I like to say adjoining,
but it should be adjourning.

23
00:00:58.910 --> 00:01:02.461
[LAUGH] Or transforming,
you gotta make them all rhyme.

24
00:01:02.461 --> 00:01:03.835
>> Yeah, it's gotta work, it's a song.

25
00:01:03.835 --> 00:01:04.625
>> It still would have them all.

26
00:01:04.625 --> 00:01:07.615
So this first one's gonna
be around the forming.

27
00:01:07.615 --> 00:01:10.655
And this is launching the team,
getting the team together,

28
00:01:10.655 --> 00:01:15.280
establishing the team and making sure
that we start on the right foot.

29
00:01:15.280 --> 00:01:18.730
And the first question you want to ask
yourself is do we even need a team?

30
00:01:18.730 --> 00:01:22.420
So the key idea there is,
would a workgroup do fine?

31
00:01:22.420 --> 00:01:24.320
Could we do individual people?

32
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:28.360
And the way you handle that is you go to
the sponsor, who is asking for the team?

33
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:32.230
You sit down and clarify, what are the
tasks we want, what's the outcome we want,

34
00:01:32.230 --> 00:01:33.930
what's the purpose of the team?

35
00:01:33.930 --> 00:01:36.860
What are you trying to achieve here?

36
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:40.240
And deciding where the sponsor,
if building a high performance team

37
00:01:40.240 --> 00:01:43.910
is actually what is necessary
to accomplish the task.

38
00:01:43.910 --> 00:01:47.110
>> John, what is the difference between,
you mentioned a work group and a team,

39
00:01:47.110 --> 00:01:48.460
what's the difference there?

40
00:01:48.460 --> 00:01:51.950
>> A work group would be a group of
individuals that basically are doing

41
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:54.150
their projects and their tasks.

42
00:01:54.150 --> 00:01:57.320
Handing them off to each other to
finish a project independently.

43
00:01:57.320 --> 00:02:00.120
There's really sort of
three levels of teams.

44
00:02:00.120 --> 00:02:05.900
There's independent teams,
interdependent teams, and dependent teams.

45
00:02:05.900 --> 00:02:08.350
On an independent team, and
I like to use sports analogies for

46
00:02:08.350 --> 00:02:10.670
this, sort of like a golf team.

47
00:02:10.670 --> 00:02:14.970
And this would be a almost close
to a workgroup where you've got

48
00:02:14.970 --> 00:02:16.570
each person individually
doing their stuff.

49
00:02:16.570 --> 00:02:18.980
On a golf team it's me versus the course.

50
00:02:18.980 --> 00:02:20.890
No one else can prep for me.

51
00:02:20.890 --> 00:02:22.010
No one else can drive for me.

52
00:02:22.010 --> 00:02:25.050
They can give me advice, but
I'm the only one responsible for

53
00:02:25.050 --> 00:02:26.860
my own score on the golf course.

54
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:29.370
Our team can win, and
we've got a team product, but

55
00:02:29.370 --> 00:02:31.690
I can also individually do very well.

56
00:02:31.690 --> 00:02:34.130
Then you have whats called
an interdependent team.

57
00:02:34.130 --> 00:02:36.190
Where we've got folks that
are handling things off, and

58
00:02:36.190 --> 00:02:39.740
am doing some work on my own, and
some of it actually as a team.

59
00:02:39.740 --> 00:02:42.600
This is more of a hybrid
from a work group coming up.

60
00:02:42.600 --> 00:02:46.590
A good analogy for that,
would be a baseball team.

61
00:02:46.590 --> 00:02:48.980
When am, I get to play banding
no body else can help me.

62
00:02:48.980 --> 00:02:51.820
They can't hit the ball for
me,they can't watch the pitch for me.

63
00:02:51.820 --> 00:02:53.370
Again, the coach can give me advice, but

64
00:02:53.370 --> 00:02:56.720
am completely on my own independent
of that part of the teamwork.

65
00:02:57.730 --> 00:03:01.100
Then you've got when you're out in
the field, you're part of the entire team.

66
00:03:01.100 --> 00:03:02.520
You're interdependent.

67
00:03:02.520 --> 00:03:05.530
If somebody hits a pot fly and
it flies by and I watch it and lands it.

68
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:09.310
I don't pick it up and throw it back in,
the team's probably not gonna win.

69
00:03:09.310 --> 00:03:11.620
So that's a different type of team,
an interdependent team.

70
00:03:11.620 --> 00:03:15.450
And finally, and this is really where
you go to high performance teams and

71
00:03:15.450 --> 00:03:19.590
the normal definition of a team which
is sort of like a football team or

72
00:03:19.590 --> 00:03:22.590
a basketball team where
it's fully dependent.

73
00:03:22.590 --> 00:03:26.520
That if one of the linemen doesn't block,
the quarterback gets sacked.

74
00:03:26.520 --> 00:03:29.040
If one of the people decides they
don't wanna pass the basketball,

75
00:03:29.040 --> 00:03:30.260
hard to win the game.

76
00:03:30.260 --> 00:03:34.235
My favorite example for
this is like an Olympic four by four team.

77
00:03:34.235 --> 00:03:36.135
If one of the folks decides
they're not going to run,

78
00:03:36.135 --> 00:03:37.830
you're not getting a gold metal.

79
00:03:37.830 --> 00:03:42.068
So step one is clearly understanding,
what kind of a team do we need.

80
00:03:42.068 --> 00:03:43.720
Would a workgroup be fine?

81
00:03:43.720 --> 00:03:45.210
Do we even need to put a team together?

82
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:47.680
>> Sounds good all right, and
I got you off task a little bit.

83
00:03:47.680 --> 00:03:51.597
So let's go back to, what was the first
step in the Bruce Tuckman model?

84
00:03:51.597 --> 00:03:52.140
It's forming.

85
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:53.280
>> It's forming.
>> Okay.

86
00:03:53.280 --> 00:03:55.680
>> So at this stage we're just
putting the team together.

87
00:03:55.680 --> 00:03:58.530
Another thing to look at is
how will the team operate?

88
00:03:58.530 --> 00:04:01.080
Is it gonna be a departmental team?

89
00:04:01.080 --> 00:04:02.280
Is it by function?

90
00:04:02.280 --> 00:04:04.190
Is it cross functional?

91
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:06.960
Is it, maybe, interdepartmental or
intercorporate?

92
00:04:06.960 --> 00:04:10.030
Maybe, it's different parts of
the company or different companies or

93
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:11.350
working with vendors.

94
00:04:11.350 --> 00:04:12.470
So, once you establish,

95
00:04:12.470 --> 00:04:16.100
all right we do need to build a team,
is it gonna be inside one division?

96
00:04:16.100 --> 00:04:18.349
Is it gonna be across divisions or
across companies?

97
00:04:19.480 --> 00:04:23.040
>> Okay and so after we're done
forming the team, you said storming.

98
00:04:23.040 --> 00:04:24.810
I'm assuming brainstorming?

99
00:04:24.810 --> 00:04:27.420
>> No, storming is when we come together
and we're gonna be covering a little bit

100
00:04:27.420 --> 00:04:30.930
later in this, is we come together and
we start working together and

101
00:04:30.930 --> 00:04:34.690
the stormy part is when people
are starting to have some friction.

102
00:04:34.690 --> 00:04:37.640
They don't know each other well,
they haven't built up a level of trust.

103
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:39.420
So it's the team sorta fighting through,
and

104
00:04:39.420 --> 00:04:42.280
storming through,
creating a more cohesive group.

105
00:04:42.280 --> 00:04:45.560
Which, the next level is then
they start performing well, and

106
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:48.910
getting better and better at what they do.

107
00:04:48.910 --> 00:04:51.820
>> Okay and so I'm not gonna try to
guess now on what norming means,

108
00:04:51.820 --> 00:04:52.910
but, help us out here.

109
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:57.250
>> Well, the norming is really the stage
where that now we've created a charter,

110
00:04:57.250 --> 00:05:00.680
we've got everybody working together
in groups, we know each other well.

111
00:05:00.680 --> 00:05:05.070
And that is the foundation of being
able to perform well together as a team,

112
00:05:05.070 --> 00:05:09.580
is having the norms across the entire
groups, shared meaning, shared values,

113
00:05:09.580 --> 00:05:13.740
a shared purpose that gets
everyone on the team aligned and

114
00:05:13.740 --> 00:05:15.360
able to deliver what's necessary.

115
00:05:15.360 --> 00:05:18.499
>> Okay, and
then finally you said, adjourning,

116
00:05:18.499 --> 00:05:20.650
adjourning gotta make it rhyme.

117
00:05:20.650 --> 00:05:21.462
So what do we mean there?

118
00:05:21.462 --> 00:05:24.330
>> Well, adjourning or actually
another word for it is transforming.

119
00:05:24.330 --> 00:05:25.360
There's two ways here.

120
00:05:25.360 --> 00:05:28.145
The team could transform,
transforming, it does rhyme.

121
00:05:28.145 --> 00:05:31.640
[LAUGH] The team could transform
to another team project and

122
00:05:31.640 --> 00:05:32.980
keep the team together.

123
00:05:32.980 --> 00:05:36.920
But often times what happens is
a team is broken up, it's adjourned.

124
00:05:36.920 --> 00:05:40.740
They disperse and then they are put on
separate teams or put on new teams.

125
00:05:40.740 --> 00:05:44.450
>> Okay so, it sounds like at the
beginning when we're forming that team and

126
00:05:44.450 --> 00:05:48.050
figuring out what kind of team we're gonna
build and what that charter is and what

127
00:05:48.050 --> 00:05:51.960
the norms are, we need to understand why
the team was created on the first place.

128
00:05:51.960 --> 00:05:55.650
So, that's going back to whoever said to,
to build the team and

129
00:05:55.650 --> 00:05:56.750
figuring that out or?

130
00:05:56.750 --> 00:06:01.330
>> Exactly right, at this stage which
one of you take some time to really

131
00:06:01.330 --> 00:06:05.110
work with the sponsor, to really clarify
what's the purpose of this team.

132
00:06:05.110 --> 00:06:06.610
What's the outcome we want?

133
00:06:06.610 --> 00:06:07.630
How will it be measured?

134
00:06:07.630 --> 00:06:10.460
In other way I like to say is
what does success look like?

135
00:06:10.460 --> 00:06:14.810
If this team operates perfectly and
delivers exactly what you want,

136
00:06:14.810 --> 00:06:18.490
how do we measure that, how will we
know that we've been successful?

137
00:06:18.490 --> 00:06:20.110
>> Basically the same as any other

138
00:06:21.190 --> 00:06:25.790
business practice your gonna have where
you want to have measurable goals and

139
00:06:25.790 --> 00:06:28.280
be able to look back and
say did we hit these or not.

140
00:06:28.280 --> 00:06:31.200
Not just kinda,
yeah I think it kinda went well.

141
00:06:31.200 --> 00:06:34.850
>> Yeah and part of that is
is once you've got that and

142
00:06:34.850 --> 00:06:37.640
you're gonna be the team leader or
you're putting the team together,

143
00:06:37.640 --> 00:06:42.840
is making sure you have the resources,
the access to people, the authority.

144
00:06:42.840 --> 00:06:45.810
So that once you've figured out
what the purpose is where we going,

145
00:06:45.810 --> 00:06:49.030
what are trying to achieve, making
sure you have everything necessary for

146
00:06:49.030 --> 00:06:52.700
you to be successful, leading that team
and taking them to the next level.

147
00:06:52.700 --> 00:06:57.600
>> Great, I know we're in kind of
a position now where in a lot of companies

148
00:06:57.600 --> 00:07:02.220
where people are spread out either in
different rooms in the same building, or

149
00:07:02.220 --> 00:07:05.960
even different buildings, or
you've got people working from home.

150
00:07:05.960 --> 00:07:09.410
What kind of challenges does that create
when putting a team together that

151
00:07:09.410 --> 00:07:13.200
might not be all in
the same actual geography?

152
00:07:13.200 --> 00:07:17.890
>> Yeah, one of the biggest challenges,
especially to do now with virtual teams is

153
00:07:17.890 --> 00:07:21.920
creating a level of trust that's necessary
to create a true high performance team.

154
00:07:21.920 --> 00:07:23.990
You can have teams that
are located together,

155
00:07:23.990 --> 00:07:28.330
colocated at different buildings or
different groups, or completely virtual.

156
00:07:28.330 --> 00:07:31.610
And what you wanna try to do is create,
again that's why that norming is so

157
00:07:31.610 --> 00:07:35.580
important, creating shared values,
a shared system, clear goals,

158
00:07:35.580 --> 00:07:39.180
a clear purpose so
that everyone is in line working together.

159
00:07:39.180 --> 00:07:41.660
And we're gonna talk about
this in later sections, but

160
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:45.550
it's absolutely essential to create
some level of bond of trust.

161
00:07:45.550 --> 00:07:49.264
So that, even though we're in different
locations, we may not see each other that

162
00:07:49.264 --> 00:07:52.235
often, we're still operating as
a group that trusts each other,

163
00:07:52.235 --> 00:07:53.421
that speaks with candor.

164
00:07:53.421 --> 00:07:55.366
That has lots of open communication,

165
00:07:55.366 --> 00:07:59.685
that has high levels of accountability
to allow us to be successful as a team.

166
00:07:59.685 --> 00:08:03.145
>> And that kinda comes back to
the norming a little bit to say Here's how

167
00:08:03.145 --> 00:08:04.409
this team is gonna work.

168
00:08:04.409 --> 00:08:06.383
It's unique for
each kind of team you're building.

169
00:08:06.383 --> 00:08:08.431
But here's what we expect of you, and

170
00:08:08.431 --> 00:08:11.253
here's how we are holding
each other accountable.

171
00:08:11.253 --> 00:08:12.332
>> Yeah, that's exactly right.

172
00:08:12.332 --> 00:08:15.542
And it's those shared values,
that foundation,

173
00:08:15.542 --> 00:08:18.081
that keeps everybody on the same page and

174
00:08:18.081 --> 00:08:22.798
allows you to hold people accountable
when they violate one of this norms.

175
00:08:22.798 --> 00:08:26.030
If they violet the value of showing up
on time, turning their work in on time.

176
00:08:26.030 --> 00:08:30.833
Not getting aggressive with
one of the other team members.

177
00:08:30.833 --> 00:08:34.209
And we'll go into a lot more depth
on that, of figuring out as a team,

178
00:08:34.209 --> 00:08:35.850
how do we wanna treat each other.

179
00:08:35.850 --> 00:08:39.976
But before even that, we gotta back up and
talk about who do we want on the team?

180
00:08:39.976 --> 00:08:44.867
And one of the exercises I use a lot with
the classes I teach is, let's create

181
00:08:44.867 --> 00:08:49.740
a model for this organization,
this group of an ideal team member.

182
00:08:49.740 --> 00:08:52.240
So for a second,
I wanna ask you a question.

183
00:08:52.240 --> 00:08:54.880
>> Okay.
>> Is when you think about someone you'd

184
00:08:54.880 --> 00:08:56.330
love to bring on your team.

185
00:08:56.330 --> 00:08:57.730
Someone that's really, really good.

186
00:08:57.730 --> 00:09:01.050
Someone that's what I would
call an ideal team member.

187
00:09:01.050 --> 00:09:01.560
What are four or

188
00:09:01.560 --> 00:09:06.040
five of the characteristics you'd look for
in a perfect team member?

189
00:09:06.040 --> 00:09:09.860
>> Well I think communication
is certainly a big one.

190
00:09:09.860 --> 00:09:13.670
When you're working with a team, it's very
different than working just by yourself.

191
00:09:13.670 --> 00:09:15.770
You've gotta be able to
talk with one another.

192
00:09:15.770 --> 00:09:19.680
It's kind of,
I'm not sure the right way to say it.

193
00:09:19.680 --> 00:09:21.630
But without kind of sounding silly here.

194
00:09:21.630 --> 00:09:24.800
But being a team player,
actually sharing ideas and

195
00:09:24.800 --> 00:09:26.620
not saying,
I wanna take all the credit for this.

196
00:09:26.620 --> 00:09:32.000
And I wanna actually work on the success
of the team as opposed to just myself.

197
00:09:32.000 --> 00:09:33.340
Those would be a couple good ones.

198
00:09:35.160 --> 00:09:39.583
Just beyond that I think, trust,
to trust that someone else is

199
00:09:39.583 --> 00:09:43.928
going to do their part and so
I don't have to worry about them.

200
00:09:43.928 --> 00:09:44.748
>> Cool, well those are all good.

201
00:09:44.748 --> 00:09:48.841
And this is a question I've asked hundreds
of companies, lots of people, and

202
00:09:48.841 --> 00:09:52.066
I actually was working with
a large organization last week and

203
00:09:52.066 --> 00:09:53.630
went through this with them.

204
00:09:53.630 --> 00:09:56.070
So I brought the actual list they created.

205
00:09:56.070 --> 00:09:57.550
And we talked about two things.

206
00:09:57.550 --> 00:10:00.230
I figured there's an interesting idea
here, and you said it sort of around,

207
00:10:00.230 --> 00:10:01.620
be a good team player.

208
00:10:01.620 --> 00:10:05.540
We also added in, what does it take to
be a great follower or team player?

209
00:10:05.540 --> 00:10:08.770
Not just a team member but
also a great follower of the team leader.

210
00:10:08.770 --> 00:10:12.320
So it's a long list and I'm gonna go
through and hit a couple of ideas.

211
00:10:12.320 --> 00:10:14.670
Number one, absolutely most important.

212
00:10:14.670 --> 00:10:18.460
And this shows up in research studies
on leadership teamwork, everything,

213
00:10:18.460 --> 00:10:22.560
is honesty, integrity,
tell the truth all the time, period.

214
00:10:22.560 --> 00:10:25.910
If you're not honest there's no way
anyone else on the team will trust you.

215
00:10:25.910 --> 00:10:28.040
If they don't trust you,
you're not a team member.

216
00:10:28.040 --> 00:10:32.520
High energy, positive attitude,
passion, enthusiasm, commitment,

217
00:10:32.520 --> 00:10:34.830
being excited about being on the team.

218
00:10:34.830 --> 00:10:37.840
Another key one, critical,
highly competent.

219
00:10:37.840 --> 00:10:39.490
You gotta be exceedingly
good at what you do,

220
00:10:39.490 --> 00:10:43.230
there's sort of a combination
here of competence and concern.

221
00:10:43.230 --> 00:10:44.820
When you're on the team, to build trust,

222
00:10:44.820 --> 00:10:48.570
people wanna see that you're extremely
good at what you do, highly competent, and

223
00:10:48.570 --> 00:10:51.130
you care about the team,
you're committed at the team.

224
00:10:51.130 --> 00:10:54.690

episodes.description: In this session you will understand how to start the team off on the right foot, the importance of creating a team charter, tools for having more effective meetings, and the four levels of decision-making on a team. You will also learn about the nine different team roles, how to set effective goals and the six characteristics of a high-performance team.
episodes.title: Establishing Guidelines, Roles and Goals

episodes.description: In this session you will look at why having a strong culture is so critical to the success of the team. You will also explore what top talent looks for when they join a team, the key characteristics of a winning culture, and the five dysfunctions that can kill a team.
episodes.title: Developing a Team and its Culture

episodes.description: In this section you will explore why having a highly engaged, loyal and committed team members is essential to success. You will look at how to build trust in an organization, on a personal level and as a team leader. You will also find out about how to overcome distrust and create a high level of commitment to the organization, to the team and as a team leader.
episodes.title: Building Trust and Commitment on Your Team

episodes.description: Being superb at effective communications is critical for the success of a team. In this session, you will learn how to ask great questions, the five levels of listening, positive body language, negative body language, social styles and other essential communications tools. You will also look at how to increase collaboration and five levels of conflict that inhibit team collaboration.
episodes.title: Team Communication and Collaboration

episodes.description: You will begin the session with a clear definition of motivation and how to create it for an individual. You also review social styles and how they directly impact motivation on a team, and the five most powerful areas of motivation. In the area of team optimization, you will learn about the five keys to creating accountability, the importance of frequent team meetings and teambuilding sessions and why analytical tools are essential in team optimization.
episodes.title: Motivating and Optimizing Team Performance

episodes.description: You will begin this session with looking at how much of the fundamental things about building great team also applies to virtual teams, the specific advantages of virtual teams, the challenge of virtual teams and the key steps to keeping the team motivated and collaborating together. You also look at how to run effective virtual team meetings, specifically what to do during the meeting and how to effectively lead a virtual team.
episodes.title: Managing Virtual Teams
